title: How the Food System Is Changing and What It Means for Investors
description: Global shifts in incomes and populations, geopolitics and climate change are combining to drastically alter the outlook for the world’s food supply.

title: Mitsotakis Wins Parliamentary Vote to Clear Way for Economy Plan
description: Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis won parliamentary backing for his government’s agenda, clearing a four-year path for improving the economy and reforming the country.

title: Kremlin Says Turkey’s Return of Azov Defenders Violates Accord
description: Turkey violated existing agreements after it returned five commanders of the Azov regiment to Ukraine, Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov told RIA Novosti.

title: Republicans Set Iowa’s First-in-the-Nation Caucuses for Jan. 15
description: Iowa Republicans scheduled the party’s caucuses for Jan. 15, setting a key date in the 2024 presidential race and solidifying the state’s influential first-in-the-nation status at least for one party.

title: Mark Rutte Bets on Hard Migration Stance for New Dutch Election
description: Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte pulled the plug on his own government by cornering coalition partners over a deal to limit the inflow of migrants, setting the stage for a more conservative campaign ahead of elections expected late this year.

title: Your Saturday UK Briefing: Investors Sour on Sunak; Hunt Goes to Mansion House
description: Follow us at  @BloombergUK and on  Facebook, and wrap up your day with The Readout newsletter.Hello from London, where it appears Rishi Sunak’s honeymoon with investors may truly be over as the outlook for inflation and growth darkens for an economy that’s already lagging behind the other G-7 nations.While investors gave Sunak credit for stabilizing the situation after his ill-fated predecessor, recent reports showing stubbornly strong wage growth and prices — are   sapping investor patience, Ph

title: Can the US-China Rivalry Benefit Both Superpowers?: Weekend Reads
description: US-China competition shouldn’t be a zero-sum game. That was the message Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen delivered during her visit to Beijing aimed at finding some common ground between the two superpowers on issues ranging from technology and trade to Taiwan’s security.

title: China Cuts Stock Funds’ Management Fees to Bolster Market
description: China’s securities regulator cut stock mutual funds’ management fees and vowed to push more institutional investors to raise equity allocations through funds, stepping up efforts to boost the market.

title: France’s Le Maire Says Policies Must Recognize Inflation Easing
Ukraine Recap: Kyiv Warns on Nuclear Plant; Cluster Bomb Debate
description: Ukrainian military intelligence warned again on the risk of Russian sabotage to the occupied Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant in southern Ukraine, saying in a report that “mines and explosives are currently being delivered” to the site. The UN’s atomic watchdog said Friday it’s seen no “visible indications of mines or explosives” in areas it has been allowed to view, while pushing for greater access.

title: Iran Executes Two Over Deadly Mosque Attack: State-Run IRNA
description: Two people were hanged in Iran early Saturday in connection with a deadly attack on a mosque last year, state-run Islamic Republic News Agency reported.

title: Macron Is Trying to Get Back on the Right Side of History — and NATO
description: The French president is pushing for the western alliance to give Ukraine a clear path to membership, but several EU allies are skeptical after a string of missteps

title: Yellen Had Candid Five-Hour Meeting With China’s He, US Says
description: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen held five hours of talks with Chinese Vice Premier He Lifeng in Beijing, the first in-depth exchange between the nations’ top economic policymakers as they seek to dial back strains in the relationship.

title: Jamie Raskin Won’t Run for Senate, Warns Democracy in Peril
description: Maryland Representative Jamie Raskin, the Democratic firebrand and constitutional law professor who led Donald Trump’s second impeachment, announced late Friday that he would forgo a run for Senate and seek reelection, citing ongoing risks to US democracy.
